name: 6-hydroxy-2,4-dimethylpyrimidine
Reason: The basic unit, pyrimidine, has a melting point of 22-23°C. The addition of hydroxyl (-OH) group generally increases the melting point due to its capability to form hydrogen bonds, which typically could add around +100°C to the melting point of the compound. Each methyl group (-CH3) generally tends to increase the melting point due to an increase in van der Waals forces as the molecular weight and surface area increase, which could add about +20°C per methyl group.
Prediction: Pyrimidine (22.5) + Hydroxyl group (+100) + 2 Methyl groups (2 x +20) = 22.5 + 100 + 40 = 162.5°C

name: 6-hydroxy-2,4-dimethylpyrimidine

Considering these effects, the adjustments for the hydroxy and methyl groups should be combined.
